  1. Analytical Geometry and Linear Algebra I
  2. 3. Matrices and Determinants, Vector Cross Product, Scalar Triple Product

3. Matrices and Determinants, Vector Cross Product, Scalar Triple Product

Author

Zakhar Podyakov

Published

September 16, 2025

1. Summary

1.1 Introduction to Matrices

A matrix is a rectangular grid of numbers arranged in rows and columns. The size, or dimension, of a matrix is given by m x n, where m is the number of rows and n is the number of columns.

  • Square Matrix: A matrix with an equal number of rows and columns (n x n).
  • Identity Matrix (\(I\)): A square matrix with ones on the main diagonal (from top-left to bottom-right) and zeros everywhere else. It is the matrix equivalent of the number 1.
  • Zero Matrix: A matrix where all entries are zero.
  • Diagonal Matrix: A square matrix where all non-diagonal elements are zero.
  • Symmetric Matrix: A square matrix that is equal to its transpose (\(A = A^T\)).
  • Triangular Matrix: A square matrix where all entries above or below the main diagonal are zero. It can be upper triangular or lower triangular.
1.2 Basic Matrix Operations
  • Addition and Subtraction: These are performed element-wise on matrices of the same dimensions. You simply add or subtract the corresponding entries.
  • Scalar Multiplication: Multiplying a matrix by a scalar (a single number) involves multiplying every element in the matrix by that scalar.
  • Transpose (\(A^T\)): The transpose of a matrix is formed by swapping its rows and columns. The first row becomes the first column, the second row becomes the second column, and so on. If \(A\) is an m x n matrix, \(A^T\) will be an n x m matrix.
  • Trace (tr(A)): The trace of a square matrix is the sum of the elements on its main diagonal.
1.3 Matrix Multiplication

Multiplying two matrices, \(A\) and \(B\), is more complex. To get the element in the \(i\)-th row and \(j\)-th column of the product matrix \(AB\), you take the dot product of the \(i\)-th row of \(A\) with the \(j\)-th column of \(B\).

  • Compatibility: For the product \(AB\) to be defined, the number of columns in matrix \(A\) must equal the number of rows in matrix \(B\).
  • Non-Commutativity: A critical property of matrix multiplication is that it is not commutative. In general, \(AB \neq BA\). The order of multiplication matters.
1.4 The Determinant

The determinant is a special scalar value that can only be calculated from a square matrix. It provides important information about the matrix.

  • Significance: A non-zero determinant means the matrix is invertible. Geometrically, the determinant represents the scaling factor of the linear transformation described by the matrix.
  • Calculation (2x2): For \(A = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix}\), the determinant is \(\det(A) = ad - bc\).
  • Calculation (3x3): This can be done using Sarrus’s rule or, more generally, through cofactor expansion.
1.5 The Matrix Inverse (\(A^{-1}\))

The inverse of a square matrix \(A\) is another matrix, denoted \(A^{-1}\), such that their product is the identity matrix (\(AA^{-1} = I\)).

  • Existence: An inverse exists only if the matrix is non-singular, meaning its determinant is non-zero (\(\det(A) \neq 0\)).
  • Adjugate Method: A common way to find the inverse is:
    1. Matrix of Minors (\(M_{ij}\)): For each element, find the determinant of the sub-matrix that remains after deleting its row and column.
    2. Matrix of Cofactors (\(C_{ij}\)): Apply a “checkerboard” pattern of signs to the matrix of minors using the formula \(C_{ij} = (-1)^{i+j} M_{ij}\).
    3. Adjugate Matrix (adj(A)): Transpose the matrix of cofactors.
    4. Inverse: The inverse is found by multiplying the adjugate matrix by the reciprocal of the determinant: \(A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\det(A)} \text{adj}(A)\).
1.6 Vector Cross Product

The cross product is an operation between two vectors in 3D space (\(\mathbb{R}^3\)) that results in a new vector.

  • Perpendicularity: The resulting vector, \(\vec{a} \times \vec{b}\), is perpendicular to both \(\vec{a}\) and \(\vec{b}\).
  • Magnitude: The magnitude of the cross product, \(||\vec{a} \times \vec{b}||\), is equal to the area of the parallelogram formed by the two vectors. The area of the triangle formed by them is half of this value.
  • Direction: The direction of the resulting vector is determined by the right-hand rule.
  • Anti-Commutativity: The cross product is anti-commutative: \(\vec{a} \times \vec{b} = -(\vec{b} \times \vec{a})\).
1.7 Scalar Triple Product

The scalar triple product involves three vectors from \(\mathbb{R}^3\) and results in a scalar value. It is calculated as \(\vec{a} \cdot (\vec{b} \times \vec{c})\).

  • Geometric Interpretation: The absolute value of the scalar triple product represents the volume of the parallelepiped formed by the three vectors.
  • Coplanarity: If the scalar triple product is zero, it means the volume is zero, and therefore the three vectors lie on the same plane (they are coplanar).

2. Definitions

  • Matrix: A rectangular array of numbers, symbols, or expressions, arranged in rows and columns.
  • Square Matrix: A matrix with the same number of rows as columns.
  • Identity Matrix (\(I\)): A square matrix with ones on the main diagonal and zeros elsewhere, which acts as the multiplicative identity.
  • Transpose (\(A^T\)): A matrix obtained by swapping the rows and columns of another matrix.
  • Determinant (\(\det(A)\)): A scalar value associated with a square matrix that determines if the matrix is invertible.
  • Singular Matrix: A square matrix whose determinant is zero, meaning it has no inverse.
  • Adjugate Matrix (adj(A)): The transpose of the cofactor matrix.
  • Cross Product (\(\vec{a} \times \vec{b}\)): A binary operation on two vectors in 3D space that produces a vector perpendicular to both original vectors.
  • Scalar Triple Product (\(\vec{a} \cdot (\vec{b} \times \vec{c})\)): A product of three vectors that yields a scalar representing the volume of the parallelepiped they span.
  • Coplanar Vectors: A set of vectors that all lie in the same plane.

3. Formulas

  • 2x2 Determinant: \(\det \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = ad - bc\)
  • Matrix Inverse (Adjugate Method): \(A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\det(A)} \text{adj}(A)\)
  • Cofactor: \(C_{ij} = (-1)^{i+j} M_{ij}\), where \(M_{ij}\) is the minor.
  • Cross Product (Determinant Form): \(\vec{a} \times \vec{b} = \det \begin{pmatrix} \mathbf{i} & \mathbf{j} & \mathbf{k} \\ a_1 & a_2 & a_3 \\ b_1 & b_2 & b_3 \end{pmatrix}\)
  • Area of Triangle (with vertices A, B, C): \(\text{Area} = \frac{1}{2} ||\vec{AB} \times \vec{AC}||\)
  • Scalar Triple Product / Volume: \(V = |\vec{a} \cdot (\vec{b} \times \vec{c})| = \left| \det \begin{pmatrix} a_1 & a_2 & a_3 \\ b_1 & b_2 & b_3 \\ c_1 & c_2 & c_3 \end{pmatrix} \right|\)

4. Mistakes

  • Assuming Matrix Multiplication is Commutative: Multiplying matrices in a different order usually produces a different result (\(AB \neq BA\)). Why it’s wrong: The row-by-column multiplication process is order-dependent.
  • Forgetting the Sign Pattern for Cofactors: When calculating the matrix of cofactors, it’s easy to forget the \((-1)^{i+j}\) term, which creates a “checkerboard” pattern of positive and negative signs. Why it’s wrong: The signs are essential for the definition of the determinant and the inverse.
  • Mistaking the Determinant of a Scaled Matrix: For an \(n \times n\) matrix, \(\det(kA) = k^n \det(A)\), not \(k \det(A)\). Why it’s wrong: The scalar \(k\) applies to each of the \(n\) rows, and the determinant is multiplicative across rows.
  • Applying Cross Product to 2D Vectors: The cross product is exclusively defined for vectors in three-dimensional space. Why it’s wrong: The concept of a single vector being mutually perpendicular to two other vectors requires a third dimension.
  • Confusing Adjugate and Inverse: The adjugate matrix is the transpose of the cofactor matrix. You must still divide it by the determinant to get the final inverse. Why it’s wrong: The adjugate is an intermediate step; without dividing by the determinant, \(A \cdot \text{adj}(A) = \det(A)I\), not \(I\).

5. Examples

Example 1: Matrix Operation Sizing (Lab 3, 1a)

Question: Given matrices P(4x5), R(5x2), and S(4x2), determine if the expression PR + S is defined. If so, what is the size of the resulting matrix?

Click to see the solution
  1. Analyze the multiplication PR:
    • P has dimensions (4 x 5).
    • R has dimensions (5 x 2).
    • The inner dimensions match (5 and 5), so the product is defined.
    • The resulting matrix PR will have the outer dimensions: (4 x 2).
  2. Analyze the addition (PR) + S:
    • The matrix PR has dimensions (4 x 2).
    • The matrix S has dimensions (4 x 2).
    • Since both matrices have the same dimensions, the addition is defined.
  3. Determine the final size: The resulting matrix will have the same dimensions as the operands, which is (4 x 2).
Answer: The expression is defined, and the resulting matrix has a size of 4 x 2.
Example 2: Matrix Multiplication (Lab 3, 2b)

Question: Given \(A = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ -1 & 2 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\) and \(B = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & -1 \\ 0 & 2 \end{pmatrix}\), compute the product AB.

Click to see the solution
  1. Check dimensions: A is (3 x 2) and B is (2 x 2). The inner dimensions match, so the product is defined. The result will be a (3 x 2) matrix.
  2. Calculate the element at Row 1, Column 1: (Row 1 of A) \(\cdot\) (Column 1 of B) = \((3)(4) + (0)(0) = 12\).
  3. Calculate the element at Row 1, Column 2: (Row 1 of A) \(\cdot\) (Column 2 of B) = \((3)(-1) + (0)(2) = -3\).
  4. Calculate the element at Row 2, Column 1: (Row 2 of A) \(\cdot\) (Column 1 of B) = \((-1)(4) + (2)(0) = -4\).
  5. Calculate the element at Row 2, Column 2: (Row 2 of A) \(\cdot\) (Column 2 of B) = \((-1)(-1) + (2)(2) = 1 + 4 = 5\).
  6. Calculate the element at Row 3, Column 1: (Row 3 of A) \(\cdot\) (Column 1 of B) = \((1)(4) + (1)(0) = 4\).
  7. Calculate the element at Row 3, Column 2: (Row 3 of A) \(\cdot\) (Column 2 of B) = \((1)(-1) + (1)(2) = -1 + 2 = 1\).
  8. Assemble the final matrix: \[ \begin{pmatrix} 12 & -3 \\ -4 & 5 \\ 4 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \]
Answer: The resulting matrix is \(\begin{pmatrix} 12 & -3 \\ -4 & 5 \\ 4 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\).
Example 3: Determinant with Scalar Multiplication (Lab 3, 2e)

Question: Given \(D = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 & 2 \\ -1 & 0 & 1 \\ 3 & 2 & 4 \end{pmatrix}\), compute \(\det(2D)\).

Click to see the solution
  1. Recall the property of determinants with scalar multiplication: For an \(n \times n\) matrix, \(\det(kA) = k^n \det(A)\).
  2. Identify n and k: Here, D is a 3x3 matrix, so \(n=3\). The scalar is \(k=2\). Therefore, \(\det(2D) = 2^3 \det(D) = 8 \det(D)\).
  3. Calculate \(\det(D)\) using Sarrus’s Rule:
    • Sum of main diagonals: \((1)(0)(4) + (5)(1)(3) + (2)(-1)(2) = 0 + 15 - 4 = 11\).
    • Sum of anti-diagonals: \((2)(0)(3) + (1)(1)(2) + (5)(-1)(4) = 0 + 2 - 20 = -18\).
    • \(\det(D) = (11) - (-18) = 11 + 18 = 29\).
  4. Calculate the final result: \(\det(2D) = 8 \times \det(D) = 8 \times 29 = 232\).
Answer: \(\det(2D) = 232\).
Example 4: Area of a Triangle (Tutorial, Problem 1)

Question: Compute the area of a triangle with vertices at A(1, 2, 0), B(3, 0, -3), and C(5, 2, 6).

Click to see the solution
  1. Define two vectors spanning the triangle from vertex A:
    • \(\vec{AB} = B - A = (3-1, 0-2, -3-0) = \langle 2, -2, -3 \rangle\).
    • \(\vec{AC} = C - A = (5-1, 2-2, 6-0) = \langle 4, 0, 6 \rangle\).
  2. Compute the cross product \(\vec{AB} \times \vec{AC}\): \[ \vec{AB} \times \vec{AC} = \det \begin{pmatrix} \mathbf{i} & \mathbf{j} & \mathbf{k} \\ 2 & -2 & -3 \\ 4 & 0 & 6 \end{pmatrix} \]
    • \(\mathbf{i}\) component: \(((-2)(6) - (-3)(0)) = -12\).
    • \(\mathbf{j}\) component: \(-((2)(6) - (-3)(4)) = -(12 + 12) = -24\).
    • \(\mathbf{k}\) component: \(((2)(0) - (-2)(4)) = 8\).
    • The resulting vector is \(\langle -12, -24, 8 \rangle\).
  3. Find the magnitude of the cross product vector: \[ ||\langle -12, -24, 8 \rangle|| = \sqrt{(-12)^2 + (-24)^2 + 8^2} = \sqrt{144 + 576 + 64} = \sqrt{784} = 28 \] This magnitude is the area of the parallelogram formed by \(\vec{AB}\) and \(\vec{AC}\).
  4. Calculate the area of the triangle: The area of the triangle is half the area of the parallelogram. \[ \text{Area} = \frac{1}{2} \times 28 = 14 \]
Answer: The area of the triangle is 14 square units.
Example 5: Finding a Matrix Inverse (Lab 3, 4a)

Question: Find the inverse of the matrix \(X = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 4 & -1 \\ 2 & 0 & 7 \\ 1 & -3 & -2 \end{pmatrix}\).

Click to see the solution

  1. Step 1: Calculate the Determinant of X. \[ \det(X) = 3(0 - (-21)) - 4(-4 - 7) + (-1)(-6 - 0) \] \[ \det(X) = 3(21) - 4(-11) - 1(-6) = 63 + 44 + 6 = 113 \] Since \(\det(X) \neq 0\), the inverse exists.

  2. Step 2: Find the Matrix of Minors. \[ M = \begin{pmatrix} (0)(-2) - (7)(-3) & (2)(-2) - (7)(1) & (2)(-3) - (0)(1) \\ (4)(-2) - (-1)(-3) & (3)(-2) - (-1)(1) & (3)(-3) - (4)(1) \\ (4)(7) - (-1)(0) & (3)(7) - (-1)(2) & (3)(0) - (4)(2) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 21 & -11 & -6 \\ -11 & -5 & -13 \\ 28 & 23 & -8 \end{pmatrix} \]

  3. Step 3: Find the Matrix of Cofactors (apply the checkerboard sign pattern). \[ C = \begin{pmatrix} +21 & -(-11) & +(-6) \\ -(-11) & +(-5) & -(-13) \\ +28 & -(23) & +(-8) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 21 & 11 & -6 \\ 11 & -5 & 13 \\ 28 & -23 & -8 \end{pmatrix} \]

  4. Step 4: Find the Adjugate Matrix (transpose the cofactor matrix). \[ \text{adj}(X) = C^T = \begin{pmatrix} 21 & 11 & 28 \\ 11 & -5 & -23 \\ -6 & 13 & -8 \end{pmatrix} \]

  5. Step 5: Calculate the Inverse using \(X^{-1} = \frac{1}{\det(X)}\text{adj}(X)\). \[ X^{-1} = \frac{1}{113} \begin{pmatrix} 21 & 11 & 28 \\ 11 & -5 & -23 \\ -6 & 13 & -8 \end{pmatrix} \]

Answer: \(X^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} 21/113 & 11/113 & 28/113 \\ 11/113 & -5/113 & -23/113 \\ -6/113 & 13/113 & -8/113 \end{pmatrix}\)
